repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: Currently there is no way of customizing behavior of
  `declaration`, `definition`, `typeDefinition`, and `implementation`
  methods in `vim.lsp.buf` when LSP server returns `Location`. Instead,
  cursor jumps to that location directly.

Solution: Normalize LSP response to be `Location[]` for those four cases.

This is another take on #23804 solution. For actual usage I'd prefer the behavior of this PR. One downside is the `on_list` naming, so I added `@notes` for all four cases.

**Edit**: I'd say that this behavior is more in line with [this comment](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/23804#issuecomment-1566673492).

**Edit 2**: Here is a [quick summary](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25830#issuecomment-1785037277) of current alternatives.

comment_data.body:
Nit, but I find this more readable:
```suggestion
      â€¢ Single location is converted to a list with a single element to allow
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1174,6 +1174,8 @@ declaration({options})                             *vim.lsp.buf.declaration()*
     Note: ~
       â€¢ Many servers do not implement this method. Generally, see
         |vim.lsp.buf.definition()| instead.
+      â€¢ Single location is converted to a list with single element to allow

@@ -1174,6 +1174,8 @@ declaration({options})                             *vim.lsp.buf.declaration()*
     Note: ~
       â€¢ Many servers do not implement this method. Generally, see
         |vim.lsp.buf.definition()| instead.
+      â€¢ Single location is converted to a list with single element to allow

comment_regular_data.body:
> Instead, cursor jumps to that location directly.

This is desired behavior; I'd be very cross if it always forced me to pick the single definition.

> > Instead, cursor jumps to that location directly.
> 
> This is desired behavior; I'd be very cross if it always forced me to pick the single definition.

It would do so only if `on_list` is explicitly specified.

> This is desired behavior; I'd be very cross if it always forced me to pick the single definition.

I actually disable the automatic jumping. With plugins like Telescope/fzf-lua that allow you to preview the definitions locations, I sometimes want to just "peek" the definition without changing my location.

> > This is desired behavior; I'd be very cross if it always forced me to pick the single definition.
> 
> I actually disable the automatic jumping. With plugins like Telescope/fzf-lua that allow you to preview the definitions locations, I sometimes want to just "peek" the definition without changing my location.

I have a dedicated `peek` function for that... (one for the protocol? ðŸ¥º )

> I actually disable the automatic jumping. With plugins like Telescope/fzf-lua that allow you to preview the definitions locations, I sometimes want to just "peek" the definition without changing my location.
> 
> > I have a dedicated `peek` function for that... (one for the protocol? ðŸ¥º )

Well the specs say nothing about what should be done with the location results. After all peek/go to are basically identical except for this behaviour with a single result. Why separate them into different functions?

Here is a summary of the alternatives without the need to study the code.

The question is what to do in `declaration`, `definition`, `type_definition`, and `implementation` methods of `vim.lsp.buf` depending on type of response **in case `on_list` is explicitly supplied**:

Response \ Code             | This PR (25830)                     | Current         | Other PR (23804) |
----------------------------|-------------------------------------|-----------------|------------------|
`Location`                    | Convert to list and apply `on_list` | Jump            | Jump             |
`Location[]` with =1 element  | Apply `on_list`                     | Apply `on_list` | Jump             |
`Location[]` with >1 elements | Apply `on_list`                     | Apply `on_list` | Apply `on_list`  |

Essentially this is a question of what to allow to be configurable in these methods. Any solution where "Jump" is present means taking some customization away from the user.

-------

My particular use case for why I consider behavior in this PR better is to use those `vim.lsp.buf` methods for a relatively easy way to create custom source for a fuzzy picker. In this case having cursor moved when `Location` is returned somewhat breaks the expectation that picker will be called.
As long as the default is still "jump if only one `Location` is returned".

> I'm just not sure about the docs. `note` admonitions always feel as if admitting defeat â€” a failure to get the point across in the previous paragraph. Or in this case, the `on_list` description.
> 
> Would something like:
> 
> ```
> on_list: (function) handler alternative result handler. See |lsp-on-list-handler|
> ```
> 
> Not suffice instead?

Well, sure, I can change that. I'd explain my reasoning first before doing so. Having extra note serves two purposes:
- Makes documentation of `on_list` uniform to indicate that it serves the same function across all `vim.lsp.buf` methods (where present).
- Clarifies that method will preprocess the LSP response to omit user surprise possibly expecting both `Location` and `Location[]` (despite the `on_list` naming).

If those are deemed to be overthinking, I'd suggest to either change nothing or to something like `on_list: (function) handler for (always) list results`.

> Makes documentation of on_list uniform to indicate that it serves the same function across all vim.lsp.buf methods (where present).

I don't see how it serves that goal anymore than the existing text and `|lsp-on-list-handler|` reference.  

> Clarifies that method will preprocess the LSP response to omit user surprise possibly expecting both Location and Location[] (despite the on_list naming).

Maybe it's too vague,  but the idea behind my suggestion was that "alternative" would signal that it replaces the default handling, and the `Location` / `Location[]` difference should be mostly irrelevant because it assumes implementation detail knowledge. The structure relevant for the user is documented under `|lsp-on-list-handler|`

How about:

```
on_list: (function) |lsp-on-list-handler| replacing the default handler
```

> How about:
> 
> ```
> on_list: (function) |lsp-on-list-handler| replacing the default handler
> ```

I like this one.  While I am here, is updating other `on_list` documentations to have this description welcome?

>  While I am here, is updating other on_list documentations to have this description welcome?

What others? The ones affected by this change - yes.  Anything else - not in this PR.

I also just noticed that there's a short circuit for empty results,  so maybe it should be:


```
on_list: (function) |lsp-on-list-handler| replacing the default handler. Called for any non-empty result 
```

> What others? The ones affected by this change - yes. Anything else - not in this PR.

Got it.

> I also just noticed that there's a short circuit for empty results, so maybe it should be:
> 
> ```
> on_list: (function) |lsp-on-list-handler| replacing the default handler. Called for any non-empty result 
> ```

Forced pushed the update.

I'd also argue that `on_list` should be called even for empty table as a result, but that is probably for another PR for all affecting handlers.

title: fix(lsp): call `on_list()` even for single location
